subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text: In {{w|Chinese character|Chinese}}, {{w|Hanja|Korean}} and {{w|Chữ Nôm|Vietnamese}} scripts, the right side component is written [[每]] (contains [[母]] with 2 dots). In Japanese {{w|shinjitai}}, the component is simplified to [[毎]] (contains [[毋]] with a single middle stroke). Due to {{w|Han unification}}, both characters ({{lang|und|sc=Hani|梅}}/{{lang|ja|梅}}) are encoded under the same Unicode codepoint. A CJK {{w|CJK compatibility ideographs|compatibility ideograph}} (U+FA44) exists for the {{w|kyūjitai}} form of {{lang|ja|梅}}.

subSections.title: Readings
Compounds
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wp|lang=ja|ウメ}} {{wp|Prunus mume}}
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|うめ}} {{IPAfont|⟨me2⟩}} → *{{IPAchar|/mːəɨ/}} → {{IPAfont|⟨mume2⟩}} → {{IPAfont|⟨ume2⟩}} → *{{IPAchar|/uməɨ/}} → {{IPAchar|/ume/}} From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=うめ|-}}.{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}{{R:Daijisen}} Found already in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'' with the ''ume'' reading, completed some time after 759 {{CE}}.{{RQ:Manyoshu|5|822}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man5Yos.html#822 here] Probably ultimately from {{der|ja|ltc|sort=うめ|-}} {{ltc-l|梅}}, with the borrowed ''me'' reading gaining a pronounced kind of initial ''m-'' sound, perhaps realized as *''mme''. The phonetic spelling was often rendered as {{m|ja||むめ|tr=*mme, mume}} from the {{w|Heian period}}, with *''mme''/''mume'' and ''ume'' apparently existing in free variation. The reading eventually settled on {{m|ja||うめ|tr=ume}}. Compare the similar pattern of phonetic shift for {{m|ja|馬|tr=ma → *mma → muma → uma||[[horse]]}}, from {{cog|ltc|-}} {{ltc-l|馬}}.

Proverbs
subSections.text: * {{ja-r|桜%切る馬鹿%梅%切らぬ馬鹿|さくら% きる ばか% うめ% きらぬ ばか}}

subSections.title: Coordinate terms
subSections.text: * {{ja-r|松%竹%梅|しょう%ちく%ばい|pos=three-level ranking system}}: {{ja-r|松|まつ|[[pine]]|pos=the top rank}}, {{ja-r|竹|たけ|[[bamboo]]|pos=the middle rank}}, {{ja-r|梅|うめ|'''[[plum]]'''|pos=the lowest rank}}
